It was the first thing I raised with the Treasurer, when he came up, and it was the first thing I was able to raise with the minister, because businesspeople were in limbo waiting for responses from their insurers as to whether they would be fully paid out. They weren't in a position to apply for a grant straightaway, and I'm extremely happy we got to put the extension forward.

I also note that many millions of dollars have been spent in my electorate, specifically on flood repairs and recovery, including: $1.7 million for the Townsville Hockey Complex; $1.5 million for the Small Business Recovery Centre; half a million dollars for flood modelling and mapping; $0.8 million for restoration of water discharge pipework; $0.7 million for restoration of water mains; and $1.6 million for infrastructure betterment works, to make infrastructure even better for when disasters do strike.

It gives me great pleasure to see that we as a government have not been sitting on our hands when it comes to rebuilding Townsville, but I also want to note that there is still much work to be done. There are still people not living in their homes. There are still sporting and community groups suffering from leaky roofs or damaged playing surfaces. There are still buildings affected by mould. There are still families suffering from the understandable long-term effects of a one-in-500-years flood event—and I say 'one in 500' cautiously, because we know that this is a number of probability; for all we know, the exact same thing could happen next year. That's why we always need to be prepared and to have the same, or even better, response times next time. Of course, living in the northern tropics, there is always the very real threat of a cyclone ripping through our region.

With that in mind, as we consider this appropriations bill going forward, I want to take this opportunity to ask the Minister for Home Affairs: can the minister please provide an update of the government's efforts to help those affected get back on their feet?

Mr GILES (Scullin) (17:39): I acknowledge the contribution of the member for Herbert and associate myself with all of his remarks. There are many things that he and I disagree on, and maybe some of them will be flushed out over the next hour or so, but the sincere way in which he has spoken about a community he loves is something that I've been personally affected by previously in this place. I acknowledge all his work and also that of his predecessor, Cathy O'Toole, in the circumstance of the floods.

I would like to address a question to the Minister for Home Affairs, but I'd like to begin with an acknowledgement of my deep appreciation of the extraordinary work—and often difficult and challenging work—done by APS employees in Border Force and other agencies connected with Immigration and Home Affairs functions. All of us in this place appreciate the challenges they face and support them in all of their endeavours. In doing so, though, I acknowledge that there are some challenges which relate to the policies and administration of this government, and these are things that we need to raise in this place and have answered by the minister. When we think about this week in Home Affairs, it's been a bad week for the department and the government. We think about the ASIO warning revelations; we think about the evidence of public opinion on medevac, which heartened many of us who want to see more humanity applied to the challenge of maintaining strong borders while treating people in our care with decency and in accordance with medical advice; and, of course, we think about the revelations exposed about the assistant minister for customs in question time today, which I hope will be properly answered very, very shortly.

But the issues with Home Affairs don't come down to a bad week or a bad day in this place; they come down to a series of deliberate decisions which have run down the functioning of the department. I was actually shocked by the recently released APS staff census, which revealed not just that Home Affairs had the worst staff engagement across the entire Public Service but also how profound the loss of confidence appears to be in this most vital agency of the Australian Public Service. The statistics are frankly shocking. They ranked 97th out of 97 for engagement and 94th out of 97 for wellbeing. It gets a bit better, Minister: 91st out of 97 for innovation. The survey also revealed that less than half of Home Affairs employees believe they have the tools and resources to do their job. That's something all of us should reflect on in this place but particularly those responsible for the administration of the portfolio. Home Affairs employees should have the tools and resources to do their work well, and the processes should allow them to be productive. We note that these findings are some way below the average across the Public Service—about 10 points below—and this has all happened after the minister cut another $150 million from the department's staff budget in this year's budget. We see evidence of what this is doing to core functions. The number of people on bridging visas has more than doubled since 2014 to 230,000 people—enough people to fill the MCG more than twice over. As of 30 June 2018, we have now a backlog of over 80,000 partner visa applications. Rather than taking steps to deal with this backlog, the minister has started to cut down on the places available, despite the law requiring spouse visas to be managed on a demand-driven basis.

Minister, was it your belief that the best method of dealing with the blowout in waiting times that has occurred under your watch was to cut funding from your own department? Minister, what steps have you taken to improve conditions, tools and resources for the department's staff members, or is your only solution to cut another $150 million from the department? I also note that it doesn't end here, because we on this side recall the $7 million allocated in the last budget for a strategic review of the portfolio with the aim of integrating capabilities, reducing duplication and maximising efficiencies within the department. Minister, perhaps you can expand on what's come from that $7 million investment that could have been better applied to supporting hardworking staff in your department to do their important functions in all of our national interest?

Mr LITTLEPROUD (Maranoa—Minister for Water Resources, Drought, Rural Finance, Natural Disaster and Emergency Management) (17:44): Can I firstly acknowledge the member for Herbert and the shining example he is not only to his community but to us. When disasters hit, as members of parliament, we sometimes find ourselves tucked away in emergency management centres taking briefs rather than leading by example—by being out in the front line with our people or on a boat or saving people out of floodwater or fires or whatever it may be. It comes from the member for Herbert's lengthy experience in the Army, his distinguished service to the nation and now to his community. Servant leadership is often overrated, but I think you're a shining example of that to this parliament and your community.

Can I assure the member that this government stands committed to rebuilding Townsville. I was fortunate enough to visit Townsville not long ago with the member for Herbert, and our financial commitment to this, along with the state government, will be over $3 billion, given the scale of this disaster. We've also made sure that we've reached out to the Insurance Council to endeavour to make sure that they meet their commitments around their policies and to their policyholders. We'll continue to work with them in a collaborative and cooperative way.

Obviously, our response has not only been to the Townsville community but the greater north-west. When we talk about the extension of the recovery grants up to the end of November, what also needs to be understood is that they were increased from $25,000 to $75,000 for primary producers and from $10,000 to $50,000 for business owners.

I was recently up in Normanton and I met a primary producer who, with tears in his eyes, said that the Prime Minister's decision to take that payment to $75,000 saved lives. It literally saved lives—such was the extent of the trauma of those people in the north-west from that event. I saw it firsthand as it was unfolding, and I've never seen anything like it before and hope never to see it again. But these people had come through the depths of despair with the drought and they had the euphoria of a 24- to 48-hour period of thinking that the drought had broken only to then slip into the absolute despair of losing everything—their income. To have leadership to that extent that understood and appreciated the magnitude of this event and increased that payment to $75,000 overnight, with the assistance of the Queensland government, meant lives were saved. We should not lose sight of that.

We continue to work, and I think we also need to acknowledge the work of Shane Stone, who is leading the recovery agency—in fact, I spent some time with him in Normanton and Karumba in the last couple of weeks. We wanted to make sure that our response was not a Canberra response, not a Canberra solution, but a local solution, on the ground. In fact, Shane is going from farm to farm to farm, making sure that those people don't think they're forgotten just because they're in north-west Queensland. He's also been to Townsville on a number of occasions working with local community groups, like the hockey club, where $1.7 million has been provided to rebuild the club. But we don't want a cookie-cutter approach, and we haven't got one.

Importantly, one of the key aspects of the recovery for those cattle producers is the $400,000 restocking and replanting grants. Never before has that sort of response by a federal government been made. This wasn't a drought, where you have the opportunity to destock and get income. These people's incomes were taken from them overnight in one event. I flew into a property where I met a producer who simply said he'd lost the lot but there was some poor bugger worse off than him, which epitomised the spirit of those people. But they were broken. The $400,000 grants will get them back on their feet. We're also working with the Regional Investment Corporation, creating an AgRebuild loan for $5 million—in fact, a couple of those have already been approved—to allow concessional rates to assist those producers to get going again.

I think we have to understand, as the member for Herbert touched on, that there is still a lot of trauma up there. As we go into cyclone season, we need to understand that. That's why we've also committed—I think more importantly than anything—$2.6 million in additional funding for mental health to make sure that those people are okay. We understand the cycles that they will go through, the events that they are about to face and the trauma that will be reawakened in their minds as we go into this summer season. Our response will be multifaceted. It will be agile. This government will continue to stand shoulder to shoulder with the people of Townsville, North Queensland and the north-west for the whole period of this recovery.

Ms CHESTERS (Bendigo) (17:49): We've heard a lot over the last two decades about people smugglers and boat people. It has become common rhetoric, particularly for the Liberal-National government, right through since the days of Prime Minister John Howard. Boat people, boat people, boat people and people smugglers—they're doing it in the best interests of shutting down people smugglers. Yet rarely do we hear the government or the minister talk about the people who are no longer choosing to travel by boat but are choosing to travel by plane—the people smuggling that is occurring by plane. In this third term of a Liberal government we've had over 80,000 people arrive in Australia by plane and claim asylum.

I accept this, and I know of and I've met people who have come here, and we've seen the cases in the media. They might have competed in the Commonwealth games or in the Olympics and then claimed asylum because of what was occurring in their home country. But that's not 80,000 people. We haven't had 80,000 people who've come here to compete in the Olympics or come here to study and then claimed asylum. There is clearly a breakdown of our borders on our planes and at our airports. This number dwarfs the number of people arriving by boat. It is 80,000 versus 1,000; that is the difference. It has been suggested that 90 per cent of these particular cases have not been found to be legitimate refugees and, doubling down on the fact that we've had cuts in the department, waiting times for processing asylum seeker cases are blowing out.

A recent report by one of the unions into this area says that people on bridging visas are waiting between one and six years. Now, some of these people have been granted work rights and, when you start to talk to these workers, where are they working? They're working on our farms. They're working in nail salons. They're working in exploitative cafes or restaurants. They're working in some quite horrific locations, and they've come forward to start telling their stories. When you ask them how they entered the country, they reply that in good faith they went to an agency or to what we in this country would call a people smuggler and said, 'I want to go and work in Australia.' They're put on a plane. They enter this country on a tourist visa. They're told: 'Come in as a tourist. Have a couple of weeks. Then come and see me.' What's then presented to them is the paperwork to apply for asylum.
The new people smuggling is not happening on boats; it's happening by plane. What is this government doing about it?
An honourable member interjecting—

Ms CHESTERS: There are people dying on our farms. People coming in this way, who don't have the proper protection and are victims of modern slavery and exploitation, are dying in this country. They're an underclass of people in plain sight in this country, but this government has done nothing on its watch. When will the department and the government actually step up and do something about this? My questions to the Minister for Home Affairs are: How many people arrived by plane and claimed asylum in 2018-19? How many of this group entered the country on a tourist visa and then claimed asylum? Which countries were they from? Are there specific countries from which they are being trafficked to here? What are the circumstances? Who is coordinating this? Who are the people smugglers? What effort is the government making to expose this and rid Australia of this scourge? They are making it incredibly hard for so many others.

I have other questions. How many people have entered the country on a tourist visa and have not left? How many have overstayed? Do we even have that fact here in this country? How many undocumented workers do we have in this country? What are we doing to crack down on people smuggling via planes and airports? What is this government doing? They are quite quick to demonise people who might try to enter the country via boat, but what about the people who are entering via plane? Many of them are victims of people smuggling. For all the crocodile tears the government have for those victims of people smuggling by boat, what are they doing about the ones who are trafficked here by plane? They walk past all of us at the airport. You see them when you get off the plane. You see the signs in language and the grabbing of people as they come past.

My final question is: have you granted or will you grant amnesty or protection to victims of people smuggling who come forward to help the government expose what's happening at our airports and on our planes and in their countries of origin?

Dr MARTIN (Reid) (17:55): I'm fortunate to represent one of the most diverse electorates in Australia. In Reid, over 50 per cent of constituents are born overseas and over 52 per cent speak another language at home. We have communities from China, Korea, Italy, Lebanon, Greece and beyond. Only last week I attended the Rhodes Multicultural Community Association's Moon Festival celebrations with my family, and the week prior I was in Five Dock celebrating the Italian festival of Ferragosto. I've had the opportunity to also visit the Sri Karphaga Vinayaker Hindu temple with Assistant Minister Wood to learn more about the Indian and Sri Lankan communities who live in Homebush and Auburn.

I have said before that being the member for Reid is like travelling around the world in one day. My electorate is an example of why we as Australians should celebrate the success of our migrant communities and recognise the significant contributions of migrants to the success of our nation. As I am the granddaughter of Greek migrants, my family and I understand the hard work and sacrifices made by migrants to provide for their families with the opportunities available to them here in Australia. Our country is made stronger because of our multicultural heritage. One in three business owners in Australia were born overseas. That diversity is certainly present in my electorate, particularly in Burwood, where we have many Chinese businesses, and we have Korean businesses in Strathfield and Italian businesses in Five Dock. I recently attended in Concord the Majors Bay Chamber of Commerce meeting. It has a large number of members from multicultural backgrounds. It is important that we as a government encourage businesses to thrive, and our migrant owned businesses are a significant component of that group.

Since the election I have had the opportunity to meet with many community organisations which provide essential support to our migrant communities. I recently visited the Chinese Australian Services Society, CASS. I understand that this is an organisation that Minister Coleman has worked closely with, given their presence in his electorate of Banks as well as in my electorate of Reid and in Bennelong to the north of me. CASS does an outstanding job in providing culturally appropriate social support to migrant communities across Sydney, particularly communities from East Asian backgrounds. The organisation offers childcare services, residential aged care, home care programs, disability support services and training to empower migrants and facilitate access to essential support services that allow these communities to thrive within Australia.

The government is also investing in social cohesion programs. During the recent election campaign, the minister joined me at Concord Oval to announce funding for the Wests Tigers, who have introduced a program designed to engage young people from diverse ethnic and cultural backgrounds, using sport to facilitate and build stronger community ties. I also joined Minister Fletcher to announce funding for the Lebanese Muslim Association, who promote social harmony in a multicultural environment.

Around the country there are many examples of organisations working to empower migrant communities at a local level, such as the Steps to Success program at Women's Health Goulburn, which is working with Sudanese and South Sudanese women to access local work opportunities. There are programs such as those run by the Islamic Women's Association of Australia, who operate the 'Parenting Between Cultures' project to support migrant parents to access resources to solve conflicts where traditional cultural values collide with Australian parenting practices.

Our government is committed to working with migrant communities to ensure they are empowered through access to employment, education, social support and inclusive community programs. My questions, then, are to the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs. What measures in the 2019-20 budget support Australia's diverse multicultural communities, such as those in my electorate of Reid? What steps is the government taking to foster integration, encourage greater social cohesion and build upon our country's successful multicultural society?

Ms KEARNEY (Cooper) (17:59): The Minister for Home Affairs would have us believe that everything in his portfolio is hunky-dory—nothing to see here, all going swimmingly. That is far from the reality. As we've already heard from a number of my colleagues, here we are descending into complete mismanagement. We've heard about the state of the minister's department and the blowout in bridging visas. We are going to hear about visa outsourcing, which could threaten our national security, we're going to hear about dodgy contracts like Paladin, and who knows what other things might be in the wind.

I would like to speak this evening about medevac. Last year, we saw a collapsing and dire health situation for refugees and asylum seekers on Manus and Nauru. The Morrison government refused to take any real action to address this crisis. We know from the work of the UNHCR, Medecins Sans Frontieres and organisations like the Asylum Seeker Resource Centre that refugees and asylum seekers detained on Manus and Nauru are sick because of indefinite detention. It is the hopelessness and helplessness of their situation which causes the high incidence of psychological issues, from depression and anxiety to the incredibly breathtaking cases of suicide. It should never have come to this. These are people, children and families who sought our protection, and I would like to make the point that there is absolutely nothing illegal about that—nothing illegal.

Billions of dollars of taxpayers' money has been spent detaining legitimate refugees and asylum seekers in detention centres, in some instances for years and years. We've heard of the enormous cost that this government has expended in fighting in the courts to prevent sick people from coming to Australia to get the care that they need. Thanks to Labor and the other minor parties, we now have the medevac legislation, which is working exactly as it should be, getting sick refugees the health care that they need. Yet this government has spent millions on silly, failed stunts simply designed to try to sway public opinion away from supporting the medevac legislation and to continue demonising refugees and asylum seekers. One of these is the now infamous press conference on Christmas Island that cost $2,000 a minute. Incidentally, the cost of reopening the Christmas Island detention centre was in the 2018-19 and 2019-20 budgets at $185 million. This cost was on the expectation the centre would have closed on 1 July and following the repeal of the medevac legislation—neither of which has happened. That centre was announced for reopening on 13 February, and sat with zero detainees until 1 September, when the poor Biloela family of four were transferred there in the middle of the night.

Medevac, the minister would have us believe, acts as a pull factor. He said rapists and murderers would come to this country. He said that the flood of people coming here would blow out our hospital waiting lists and keep Australians out of hospitals. We know that none of that is true. We know that none of that has happened. But we know that a concerted effort in transit and source countries to stop the dreadfully dangerous and exploitative trade of people smuggling does have an effect. Right now, the federal government has four Federal Police officers in source countries in our region. The government has dramatically reduced the number of officers in those areas. So if the government is serious about preventing people getting on dangerous and leaky boats, then it must invest in a robust presence in source countries and countries of transit, and not spend all of its energy fighting against the medevac legislation, which provides a humanitarian approach to enable proper medical treatment for people in Australia's care. This government can and must act immediately by taking up resettlement offers from New Zealand and by putting resources into this. It can and must stop people who are seeking asylum and refugees, when they are here in our community amongst us, from being homeless, starving and not getting access to basic human rights. It must restore hope, because it is the absolute loss of hope that destroys people and breaks them.

So my question is: can the government tell me why it is spending millions on ridiculous stunts, like reopening Christmas Island, rather than properly funding the Australian Federal Police to work in source countries and countries of transit to prevent people from making dangerous sea journeys?

Mr STEVENS (Sturt) (18:05): It's my pleasure to speak on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2019-2020 and in particular on a topic that's very close to my heart, which is population growth in my state of South Australia. The appropriation bill that we are debating today sees a very important and significant development in this government's approach to migration policy. I'm very proud to be a part of the Morrison government and the way in which we are moving away from a one-size-fits-all approach to population growth in our country towards instead understanding that there are some parts of this country that have been growing very strongly for a long period of time. That has brought certain pressures to some parts of the country, particularly to big cities like Sydney and Melbourne, and to South-East Queensland. Lots of Labor state governments have failed to invest, frankly, in the kind of infrastructure that they should have invested in to support population growth, and that's put a lot of pressure on certain parts of the country. It's sensible and prudent that we consider whether or not some of those growth rates have been a little high.

In my state of South Australia, it's been quite the opposite. We've been growing at a very low rate compared to the national average for a long time now. The national population growth rate is about 1.6 per cent at the moment—it's been sitting pretty consistently for a number of years—but in South Australia it's 0.8 per cent. It's been half the national average very consistently. In fact, we've been about the seventh-fastest-growing jurisdiction of the eight states and territories for more than 10 years now—so just off the bottom rung, but consistently. Victoria is growing at about 2.2 per cent at the moment, and yet we're growing at 0.8 per cent. This puts an enormous amount of economic pressure on our state, and in many ways it's really a ticking time bomb. An ageing population and a slow growth rate mean that we're going to have an ever-diminishing component of our population in the workforce paying taxes and contributing to an economy that can support people, quite rightly, as they retire and as they have a need for increased expenditure in government services.

What the government is doing is recognising this and introducing a much-expanded focus on regionally-targeted migration programs. I note that we intend to now have 23,000 places in our migration program for people who are seeking visas to go into regional areas. I wouldn't ordinarily describe my great city of Adelaide as 'a regional area', but I'm glad that it is designated as a regional area by the government for the purposes of this program. Quite rightly, Melbourne, Sydney, South-East Queensland and, at the request of the Western Australian government, Perth—which I find odd, but that's up to them—are not considered regional areas, but the rest of the country is. That, of course, includes Adelaide. This is really important, because of that 0.8 per cent growth rate that I've talked about.

Things are bright now in South Australia—we've gotten rid of a terrible Labor government; we are focused on growing our economy; we are focused on the jobs and industries of the future; we've got great opportunities in defence and cyber, and a space agency is being headquartered in South Australia; and we've got very strong traditional industries around mining, agriculture, wine, et cetera. There is a bright future, but we need to address this long period of subpar population growth. We're going to see a bright future through these programs—I think that South Australia will do very well out of that 23,000 figure. I think that, hopefully, we will get a very significant share of that.

As the opportunities start to bear fruit and come online from the great work and partnership between this federal Morrison and the state Marshall government, I think the natural momentum of the economy is going to engender a lot of reverse brain drain. We've seen for a long time that so many young people in South Australia have had to leave the state, because the opportunities for their career advancement have not been in Adelaide. We are turning that around, and this program is going to be a very important short-term shot in the arm to get some momentum going, and then I think we'll achieve some real consistency going forward from these great policy measures.

My question to the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs is: what measures in the 2019-20 budget are helping to reduce the population pressure on our major capitals and address skills shortages in regional Australia? And what measures in the 2019-20 budget are encouraging migrants to live, work and study in regional Australia?

Mr BURNS (Macnamara) (18:10): I want to start by saying that the member for Cooper's remarks before are a good reflection on the fact that, ever since the member for Cooper has come into this parliament, she's been a voice for compassion, a voice for decency and a voice for people who need a voice. I can't say the same for everyone else. I want to acknowledge the member for Cooper, because we could all be a little bit more like the member for Cooper.

It is good to have the Minister for Home Affairs and the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs in the chamber tonight. I too want to touch on some of the themes raised by the member for Cooper. I want to take us back to the medevac bill—a bill that was passed in the previous parliament when, for the first time in 90 years, the government lost a vote on the floor of the House of Representatives. If you remember at the start of the week, the member for Maribyrnong took a whole range of security briefings to make sure that the medevac bill was limited in its scope and appropriate, and to make sure that the medevac bill couldn't be twisted in any other way other than to help people who needed medical attention. The member for Maribyrnong put forward amendments and worked with the crossbench to put through a bill. Amazingly, they got that bill through the House of Representatives.

What did we see from the government as a result? We saw their usual tactics—what they always revert back to. We saw the government not talk in policy and truth; we saw the government resort to fear and division and we saw the government do one of the most expensive political stunts, I think, in this country's history. They opened the Christmas Island detention centre. What a waste of money to spend $185 million for a press conference backdrop, and for a pretty lousy press conference, if I may say so. I will never have $185 million in my entire life, no matter what happens with inflation in this country. And yet this government decided to spend $185 million to open the Christmas Island detention centre. The best piece of evidence to prove that this was not about policy or about actually doing something that had any relation to the medevac bill is the fact the Christmas Island detention centre didn't have hundreds of people in there; it had zero. Not one person went into the Christmas Island detention centre after the government spent $185 million on it. Not one person! So then what did we see? We had seen this great waste of money where the government spent $185 million to look over absolutely no-one for a cruel political stunt, and then we saw the situation where a family in regional Queensland, who had gotten to know the community and who'd been welcomed by the community, was sent to the centre in the middle of the night. It's not just the Labor Party who were calling for this family to be able to stay in this country. The member for Flynn—I'm sure those on the other side will agree he's a hardworking local member—wanted this family to stay. The Member for New England, another hardworking local member—perhaps some might say very hardworking—wants this family to stay. And Alan Jones— I don't listen to him that much—wants this family to stay. You would say none of them are ardent Labor supporters, and yet they all want the family to stay. And what does the government do? In the middle of the night they take a four-year-old girl and a two-year-old girl to the Christmas Island detention centre just to scare them. That doesn't take strength; that's just cruel. So we've had a political stunt for $185 million, and then we've taken a two-year-old girl and a four-year-old girl into this political stunt, into the middle of the night. It's a disgrace.

My question to the minister is: if the cost to open a detention centre for zero detainees was $185 million, has that cost risen as a result of having four detainees? If the cost was $185 million on the basis that the centre would have closed 2½ months ago, has that cost risen as a result of the centre being open for an extra 2½ months?

Mr COLEMAN (Banks—Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs) (18:15): I thank members for their contributions to the debate. I want to thank members for raising really important issues around regional immigration and the importance of Australia's multicultural, diverse society. I want to speak to those issues, and I want to touch on a couple of points raised by those opposite as well.

Firstly, on our government's population plan, the fact is that we as a nation have seen significant population pressures, particularly in Sydney and Melbourne. So what the government has done this year is cut the permanent cap on the migration program to 160,000 places. Allocating 23,000 visas for people who commit to living and working in regional Australia for three years will enable more of those places to be based in regional Australia. That's a very important initiative, Mr Deputy Speaker, and no doubt you would have observed that the permanent migration plan outcome in 2018-19 is the lowest it has been for some 10 years.

We have reduced the permanent migration intake and we are putting greater emphasis on migration in regional areas, because there are so many places around Australia—South Australia is one, but there are many others—where regional communities are crying out for more skilled immigration and for more skilled migrants to join their communities and help to grow their community and population. The government is very focused on that initiative. We have also provided additional incentives for working holiday-makers in this year's budget. They will get to stay in Australia for a third year if they commit to a regional area. And, of course, we have done some seven designated-area migration agreements in regional Australia to work with local communities, to help provide that skilled migration that's so important.

I also want to comment on the member for Reid's questions regarding the importance of multiculturalism in Australia. The Prime Minister often says, 'We are the greatest migrant nation in the world,' and he is absolutely right. In this country, what matters is not your racial background, your religion or your cultural background but who you are. What matters is your character, your conduct and what you bring to this country. Since the Second World War in particular, we have been so fortunate as a nation to grow through the contribution of so many migrants—the people who work hard, play by the rules and observe the laws of Australia; the people you will see in every football club, in every church and in every town and suburb of this nation. The member for Reid understands that incredibly well, because she has one of the most multicultural and diverse electorates anywhere in the nation. She is a tremendously powerful advocate for those communities, and she knows that the government's $71 million social cohesion package, which we announced in this year's budget, is so important because the Fostering Integration Grants program helps to back multicultural communities. There are our community language grants, part of a $10 million program to help Australian kids to learn more about their cultural heritage through the language of their forebears; it might be through going to a Greek school or a Vietnamese school or a Mandarin school, as the case may be.

Multicultural Australia has a culture of growth, not grievance. Growth in opportunities, growth for the next generation, growth in freedom—they are the things that are great about our country, they are the things that attract so many migrants to our nation and they are the things that we are so proud to achieve. But, in order to achieve that, you have to have integrity and sovereignty in your system. That is something that this government understands incredibly well and has been extraordinarily successful at, through the Prime Minister and the Minister for Home Affairs ensuring that we have security and sovereignty in our immigration system so that we can plan and we can support those people who work hard, play by the rules and want to come to and contribute to our nation.

We will never, ever take lectures from the Labor Party on these matters, because we know that when they were in power 1,200 people drowned at sea. We know that 8,000 kids were locked up against their will—forcibly placed in detention—and some 50,000 people arrived by boat, not to mention the fact that it has cost Australian taxpayers close to $20 billion. So we will never, ever take a lecture from those opposite, because we understand how to run a sovereign, orderly immigration system that is in the interests of this nation.

Mr GILES (Scullin) (18:20): The bushfires that have been raging in Queensland and New South Wales demonstrate the importance of increased disaster mitigation and recovery funding. Can I join the Leader of the Opposition, the Prime Minister and others to express my gratitude to our emergency services personnel and volunteers who have bravely fought dangerous fires, and I express my support for all of those homeowners who have lost their properties. Labor believes it's a fundamental responsibility of government to protect Australians, help communities to mitigate against the devastating effects of disasters, support them when disasters strike and properly fund relief efforts to rebuild.

In this year's budget the creation of a new emergency relief fund has been announced, to provide funding for emergency response and recovery following significant natural disasters. This week the minister introduced the Emergency Response Fund Bill 2019 to establish this fund. It is proposed this fund will distribute up to $150 million per year for disaster recovery activities. As has been stated by the Leader of the Opposition, the opposition supports government taking action to help communities recover and also supports mitigation measures to build resilience. But there are problems with this fund.

First, despite the many calls from interested parties for extra mitigation funding, there is no guarantee that a single cent from the fund will be spent on mitigation. The coalition has failed on mitigation, having only agreed to provide $26.1 million per annum for disaster resilience under the current national partnership agreement with the states and territories. Even the amount provided by this fund falls short of the Productivity Commission's 2015 recommendation that the Commonwealth provide $200 million per year in resilience funding. Second, the fund would only provide for funding of mitigation infrastructure after a disaster has struck, rather than funding, for example, a flood levy or cyclone shelter before the event.

Finally, and perhaps most significantly, in creating the fund, the government is pitting two worthwhile aims against each other. The government's plan is to fund natural disaster recovery by cutting funding from nation-building education infrastructure. Labor established the Education Investment Fund in 2009 to address years of underinvestment from the Howard era and to transform Australia's education and research capacity. This fund provided important capital funding to update and modernise Australia's vocational and higher education research facilities, enabling the sector to grow jobs, generate research breakthroughs and compete for international students. What we need is to keep this fund going. It is a sad reflection of the government's priorities that it wants to wind up nation-building funds to make up for its failures to properly invest in disaster mitigation and recovery. We should be properly funding education and natural disaster recovery and mitigation.

So my question to the Minister for Water Resources, Drought, Rural Finance, Natural Disaster and Emergency Management is: why won't he provide much-needed financial assistance to communities affected by emergencies and natural disasters without cutting funding from education?

Mr SIMMONDS (Ryan) (18:23): A generous migration scheme that prioritises those who are willing to roll up their sleeves and contribute is vital to ensure strong communities and a strong nation. It has served the Ryan electorate, my electorate, particularly well. Our most famous migrant is Professor Ian Frazer, inventor of the Gardasil cancer vaccine.

It is a deep and solemn pact that we have with the Australian people. We are a people that are generous and welcoming, not in spite of but exactly because we have tight control of our borders and are exacting against criminal elements that come here and then abuse our trust. We must always seek to honour this unwritten compact with the Australian people, by resisting efforts which weaken control of our borders or weaken our ability to keep our citizens safe. That's why the allocation in this part of the budget is so vital to Australians and to the residents of my electorate of Ryan.

I was recently talking in the chamber about the strengthening of the character test, and Labor are all over the shop on this issue. I have seen Labor play politics with a lot of issues in this parliament over the last couple of weeks, whether it be drought funding, natural disaster funding, stopping union lawlessness, the budget or the economy. But the idea that they could be so out of step with the Australian community that they think it is acceptable that long-term or short-term visa holders who are convicted of serious criminal offences should not be deported just because they didn't get a sentence over 12 months is extraordinary. This could lead to situations, like the home affairs minister pointed out in question time today, where there is a risk of reoffending in Australia. A situation which struck a chord with me was where a woman was murdered by her ex-partner, and the ex- partner was convicted in 2010 of malicious intent, stalking and threatening behaviour but received a sentence of less than 12 months. With the new amendments that we are putting through the chamber, that would have been enough to trigger the character test and have that person deported, and they wouldn't have been here three years later to have followed through on their threat to their partner, which was tragic.

Do you know why the Labor Party were in the chamber today opposing these new amendments? Because they are more in touch with the New Zealand Prime Minister than they are with Australians. Their argument against strengthening these amendments was that 44 per cent of the people who we are deporting back to New Zealand are reoffending. So their argument was perverse. They were saying, 'Let's keep them here so they can reoffend in Australia.' And why would they say this? Because some of them have stayed here longer than 10 years. They'd like a phased-in approach like New Zealand has so that if somebody's been in Australia on a long-term visa for over 10 years they can't be deported.

The idea that time alone should be the critical factor of whether you are a fit and proper character to stay in the Australian community is absurd. It should be about your actions and whether you honour Australia's generosity, contribute to your community and roll up your sleeves. It's an insult to the migrants who do, who are on short- and long-term visas, and who want to keep their own families safe and contribute to the community.

This is why I'm so passionate about making sure that this particular area of the budget continues to keep us safe. That's why since August 2014 the government has strengthened our nation's defences against terrorism, investing an additional $2.2 billion. The government has passed 18 tranches of legislation covering matters, including continued detention of high-threat terrorists and strengthening control orders in order to minimise the threat to the public. Yet we know there continue to be pressing threats to our sovereignty, and criminal syndicates, like people smugglers, are watching our nation very closely. We know that those attempts have been made only very recently and we know that, under Labor, when you pull apart their strong border regime, what do you get? Around 50,000 people arrived illegally on more than 800 boats and more than 1,200 people drowned at sea. It's an absolutely disgraceful record that Labor fails to defend every day. Some 8,000 children were placed in detention, reaching a peak of almost 2,000 in July 2013. So, for that very reason, we don't want a repeat of that. My question is to the Minister for Home Affairs. Can the minister confirm how the government is working to keep Australians safe, including through the 2019 budget?

Mr BURNS (Macnamara) (18:28): This government is tough on refugees but weak on bigots. Let's go through a few cases, shall we? Stanislaw Michalkiewicz, a Polish anti-Semitic hate preacher, was granted a visa to deliver a speaking tour across Australia. Mr Michalkiewicz is affiliated with the Polish far Right, is a shock jock who attacks Holocaust survivors and their descendants and has also equated child sexual abuse victims with prostitutes. He deserves a visa and he deserves to be welcomed into this country, according to this government.

Then we had the case of David Icke, a British conspiracy theorist—and I note the immigration minister is in the chamber tonight. After I wrote to the minister and after considerable community outrage, the government granted David Icke, a British Holocaust denier and conspiracy theorist, a visa. I can't even imagine the process that would have gone on in the department to think: 'Tick: bring this guy into Australia. Let him come and do his best work because Australia's going to be much better off by having someone like David Icke come to this country.' Yet the government allowed David Icke to come to this country. Only after a community campaign did the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, who is in the chamber tonight, reverse that decision and say that David Icke wasn't allowed to come to this country. I should put on the record that I think the minister eventually backed down and made the right decision.

Another case is that of Milo Yiannopoulos, one of the world's most notorious far Right extremists, a man with extensive links to white supremacists, a man who glorified Nazi ideology and used Nazi references to harass Jewish journalists and a man who has a history of vilifying all sorts of minorities and also of defending paedophiles. He was granted a visa against the department's advice. Frank and fearless advice, and the minister overruled the department and granted him a visa, but then only backed down after the Christchurch massacre. That's what it took to make sure Milo wasn't allowed into this country, because I know a lot of members of the government wanted to get a selfie with him!

Then we had the CPAC conference, with speakers like Raheem Kassam, a far Right extremist with a history of vilifying women, racial and religious minorities, and LGBTQI among others. He was granted a visa, as were American far Right gun fanatics, like Matt Schlapp, who was called out for racist dog-whistling by American conservatives and former Republican chair—not Democrat, but Republican—Michael Steele. They were all granted a visa despite considerable public pressure. All of these people are hate preachers who come to this country seeking commercial gain, trying to do speaking tours to spout their ideology, yet the government allows them in. My question to the minister today is: what policy does the government have to make sure hate preachers aren't allowed into this country, that people who are not fit and proper don't come to Australia to seek commercial gain? Does the character test have any clear standards or criteria or is it just about whether or not the Liberal caucus want to have selfies with them?

Mr DUTTON (Dickson—Minister for Home Affairs) (18:32): I want to say thank you very much to all of the colleagues who have contributed to this debate. I want to acknowledge the work of the officers in my department in particular, who do an exceptional job, many of them in very difficult circumstances. It's very hard for many Australians to relate to the working environment of officers of the Australian Border Force, ASIO, the Australian Federal Police, the ACIC—those that are involved day and night in keeping Australians safe. That's why the government's budget this year is a very significant injection into the department to support the work of those officers. First and foremost, I want to pay tribute to all those officers. I also want to pay tribute to many of my colleagues who have supported the work of the department for a very long time, and to those members who are new to this parliament, I say thank you very much, in particular for the contributions of the member for Ryan and the member for Herbert. They have a very significant understanding because they relate to their community. They understand that the work within this department remains an absolute priority for their constituents, and, therefore, their support of the officers within the Home Affairs portfolio is very much appreciated.

If I can address a couple of points specifically that were raised by colleagues on both sides of the chamber in this debate: firstly, as we know, the government, through the agencies, work very hard to keep Australians safe. The counterterrorism threat level is at 'probable' and the agencies have been able to thwart now 16 attempted attacks on our country, and it has saved Australian lives. We should never forget the true impact that a terrorist attack has on a democracy like ours; we've seen it elsewhere in the world, and we've seen some attempts here which could have been much more impactful had those people had automatic firearms or had there not been a quick response by the first responders on the ground. We contribute to the home affairs portfolio this year $6.4 billion, which is a significant investment. We do that because we can manage the budget well. We have taken tough decisions over the last six years to balance the budget, which was a disaster in the Labor years. They gave money to people who spent it on solar panels, pink batts and school halls. We have worked tirelessly to get the budget back into balance, but, at the same time, we have been able to make significant contributions in the areas of defence, national security, health, education and, otherwise, across areas such as the NDIS. At the same time, we recognise that there is a lot more work to do.

We are spending less money on regional processing because we aren't pulling 1,000 people a week off boats, as the Labor Party were when they were in government. What I'd say to the Australian public is: if you want an insight into the lunatic Left element of the Labor Party, tune in to the contributions you've just heard from some of the members of the extreme Left of the Labor Party. It's no wonder that every Labor leader has struggled to keep the lunatic Left of the Labor Party in check. When you hear contributions such as some of those we've heard today, is it any wonder that thousands of people arrive by boat? The Labor Party have never been able to hold a coherent position when it comes to border protection. When you look at the footage of the contributions of those opposite, you can only imagine what they are saying in private to the Leader of the Opposition.

On issues such as that of the Sri Lankan family that has been in the press in recent weeks, it is no wonder, given the contributions of those opposite, that the Leader of the Opposition decided to go out to Biloela—no doubt at the behest of many of those opposite—to listen to the case and then never asked a question or uttered any word about that issue from that day to this. I've been waiting in parliament for a question on this important issue that required the Leader of the Opposition to charter an aircraft and fly out to Biloela. He come back here and has not said a word. He has not ever mentioned the case again. It shows that the leaders of the Labor Party have a most difficult job. I have sympathy for them. I really do. The member for Maribyrnong was tying himself in knots. Ms Gillard did so before that. Of course, Kevin Rudd was dysfunctional. But we have, no doubt, some continuing sympathy for the current Leader of the Opposition because he has to manage this rabble. It is no wonder that, I suspect, he is coming up to the last days of his leadership as well.
We won't take moral lectures from those opposite. We never ever will because we maintain border protection and we'll keep Australia safe.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Consideration in Detail
Proposed expenditure, $1,356,740,000

Mrs ANDREWS (McPherson—Minister for Industry, Science and Technology) (18:37): I'm very pleased to speak about the budget in this debate today and also discuss some of the more recent measures in my portfolio of Industry, Innovation and Science. Investments in industry, innovation, science and technology drive economic growth and job creation in Australia, helping business thrive and meet the many challenges that exist in today's economy. The Morrison government is committing to driving all industries—both emerging and traditional—forward and ensuring all Australians are equipped with the skills they need for the jobs of the future. One of the most important aspects of this budget is that we are delivering a surplus to get the budget back in the black and back on track. Strong economic management is the bedrock for Australian industry. It's also essential to be able to encourage and support science and innovation. So the very best thing we can do as a government is get the basics right and balance the budget. It's something Labor and the Greens never seem to understand. Because we are responsible economic managers, our government is able to invest more than $170 million in spending measures for industry, science and technology through this bill. Among many other things, this includes funding for the Space Infrastructure Fund and measures to encourage and develop STEM capability to build a stronger workforce.

I want to keep this opening statement brief so I have maximum time to respond in this debate, and later I will expand on how we are delivering our election commitments in my portfolio, including the $50 million Manufacturing Modernisation Fund, $5 million to reinvigorate the Australian Made Campaign and $5.2 million to assist migrants to establish a start-up business. During the remainder of this debate, I look forward to discussing these positive policies that our government is delivering and outlining how this budget benefits all Australians, including those many quiet Australians who put their faith in us at the election in May.

Mr BRENDAN O'CONNOR (Gorton) (18:40): This government is in denial about the role it needs to play in the public safety issue of construction quality and flammable cladding. That's what I want to discuss this evening and I also want to ask questions of the minister. Clearly, while it is a federal responsibility—and other jurisdictions have prime responsibility in some of the areas that go to the building industry, particularly going to this question of the flammable cladding product—there are issues that are the direct responsibility of the Commonwealth. There are issues that need to be attended to by the Morrison government and by the minister on the other side of the chamber that have yet to be attended to.

We do know, of course, that the problems in the building industry have been going on for some years. We also know that the minister who is now responsible for this department was the assistant minister responsible for this particular issue. We also know that there are many things that state governments have to do to make sure that the public is safe and that tenants in dwellings that may have this flammable cladding as part of the construction are also safe. Therefore, there needs to be some leadership at the federal level to ensure that there is a proper response to this potential public crisis in the building industry. What we do know is that many professionals are struggling to secure indemnity and struggling to acquire insurance in the building industry because of the uncertainty and the risks. We do know of the failure of the Morrison government to attend to phoenixing in this country, in particular in the building industry, and the failure to have significant and appropriate legislation in place to tackle the absolutely outrageous conduct by companies and directors who, quite often, leave creditors in their wake, close down companies, start them up again and, of course, avoid their obligations, and we know that these are also the same companies that are involved in improperly using products that could potentially lead to the deaths of Australians in those dwellings.

There are hundreds, if not thousands, of dwellings across the country which need to be properly audited. They have to be properly dealt with. The Commonwealth needs to put in place laws to respond to these cowboy companies who act so improperly, yet they fail to do so. Even today in the parliament, we have legislation that doesn't include provisions that were in prorogued bills of the last parliament. We had the government clearly agreeing at one point to having a director identification number to make clear the accountability that directors must have to ensure with greater clarity the identity of directors of companies, yet those provisions have been taken out of the proposed bill before the parliament. So the minister responsible and, indeed, the minister in this chamber now need to deal with phoenixing, which is rife in the building industry; they need to deal with questions around the auditing of buildings; and they need to deal with the issues of uncertainty, and the resulting failure of professionals in the building industry to be able to access insurance, because of the uncertainty and the risks. And it's no good having a meeting with counterpart ministers in other jurisdictions, coming out, calling a press conference and saying, 'We've fixed everything. We've got a report. We've got the Shergold Weir report. We're going to deal with all of those recommendations.' This has gone on now for years. We've seen disasters in other countries, like the Grenfell Tower disaster—a tragedy the like of which we hope never happens in this country. But disasters can happen, and we need to avoid those types of risks. We can only do that by ensuring that the government attends to these matters. It's critical that the government does that. Before the government says and before the minister suggests that there is no responsibility for the Commonwealth in relation to audits, of course, they're responsible for the ACT. We need to know what's happened in this jurisdiction.

The fact is we need to ensure that all parts of Australia have a proper audit. My question to the minister is: has the government completed the audit of all buildings on Commonwealth land or leased by Commonwealth departments? That's an important question. Whilst the government may want to blame state governments for not acting, my question is: more specifically, has the government completed the audit of all buildings on Commonwealth land or leased by the Commonwealth department, and will that information be publicly released, if indeed that has been undertaken?

Mr RAMSEY (Grey—Government Whip) (18:45): Quite excitingly, the 2019-20 budget provided $19.5 million for the Space Infrastructure Fund, and I want to speak on that today. I welcome the government's ongoing interest in this area. My electorate has a strong connection with the space industry, through what is now the RAAF Woomera Range Complex, the largest land based test range in the world, at 127,000 square kilometres. To put that into context, it is about double the size of Tasmania. So it is a good place to have a play around with a bit of equipment like some satellite-launching gear. It has been important to this nation and it will continue to be.

In recent years we have seen large upgrades on the range—$297 million to rebuild the digital monitoring and communication technologies across the range. Significant further investment is under further consideration. Maybe we will never see a return to the glory days of Woomera when there were more than 6,000 people living there, but there is a significant whiff of revitalisation in the air. Woomera is ideally well-placed to provide significant services to our new commitment to the space industry.

Last month I met with a consortium, Southern Launch. They are hoping—in fact they are planning—to launch satellites off the southern Eyre Peninsula, not the big geostationary satellites that we have become familiar with but new-age, low-orbiting satellites. These will operate about 400 kilometres above the earth's surface. Geostationary satellites are at about 35,000 kilometres. If we are talking about delay in communications—you might get your head around that—this is a much shorter distance, virtually instant. There will be no drag in that communication chain. It is highly likely that hundreds if not thousands of these will be launched over the next decades.

They have a useful lifespan of about two-and-a-half years, and they fall back to earth after about four years and burn up completely in the atmosphere because they are not big. Southern Launch are very confident that, should they get a foothold in this industry, we can build an industry in South Australia by building these satellites, because they are quite small; we are talking kilograms rather than tonnes. I look forward to working with them and helping them fulfil their dreams.

My understanding is the Space Infrastructure Fund will back priority projects across states and territories and address the gaps, transforming the Australian industry. So far, the government has committed $73.2 million to support the development of Australia's space sector, including $32.7 million towards the ongoing operation of the Australian Space Agency, $15 million for the International Space Investment Initiative, and $6 million for the Space Discovery Centre announced as part of the Adelaide City Deal.

I know the government understands the profound benefits of space technology and services on the lives of Australians—it touches virtually every one of us. Australian farmers—and you, Mr Deputy Speaker Rick Wilson, and I are both farmers—already value the space industry and the capabilities that are offered to us to monitor on-farm the health of our crops. Marine pilots use GPS guidance. They guide cruise-liners. Emergency workers track the progress of bushfires. Scientists study the effects and impacts of droughts. I know, as a proud South Australian, that much of the space industry activity is centred in South Australia. The headquarters of the Australian Space Agency will be at located at Lot 14 in Adelaide.

Mission control facilities under the Space Infrastructure Fund will provide a platform for small and medium enterprises or researchers to control small satellite missions and provide access to space enabled data. The $6 million Australian Space Discovery Centre is part of the Adelaide City Deal, and is funded separately, not as part of the Space Infrastructure Fund. Geoscience Australia's investment in South Australia includes $14 million over the forward estimates for the ground station infrastructure. The new SmartSat Cooperative Research Centre is also being headquartered in South Australia. The SmartSat CRC will create leapfrogging technologies in advance of telecommunications and smart satellite systems to build Australian space infrastructure. I appreciate the minister further outlining now how this commitment to science and space technology in this budget will deliver real benefits and create jobs in South Australia and all around the nation.

Mr SNOWDON (Lingiari) (18:50): I want to say thank you to you, Mr Deputy Speaker Rick Wilson, because I travelled through part of your electorate recently to sample northern Australian roads. It's northern Australia that I want to talk about tonight because, while it has been given a lot of promises and a lot of undertakings, not a lot has happened. We have seen the NAIF not produce a great deal, not a lot of money is coming out the door, and that's been a cause of frustration for many. I'd like to know from the minister what NAIF projects are currently in play. When are we likely to see more NAIF money being announced to support projects in northern Australia? I know there are concerns from some proponents that the NAIF is not wanting to support some big proposals because of their assessment of risk on returns, even though private sector finance will be made available for these projects should NAIF funds be made available as a stimulus.

Mr Deputy Speaker, these are important issues, as you would know, for people who live in northern Australia and regional Australia generally. I'd like to know what the NAIF is doing to attract and support smaller proposals, particularly from First Nations organisations to set up small businesses, and how it is working with these businesses, if it is working with them at all, to mitigate any risks in their investment profiles. I know of one group, for example, in the Victoria River region who have a $4 million guaranteed contract on Defence land at the Bradshaw training range, but they require capital to buy equipment to be able to undertake the contract. Would NAIF be an attractive proposition for these people, or what other government agency might there be to assist them in acquiring the capital they require to get the equipment to undertake the contract? The contract itself is guaranteed. It's a huge area of land they'd be assisting to look after for the Department of Defence.

This is an important question, and it arises because of the belief from First Nations people across northern Australia that they are not being engaged with properly by government to assist them to get the benefits of the announcements which have been made. I'd like to know what actions the government is intending to take or thinking about to assist First Nations people to leverage their asset base. I say that knowing, as you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that around 50 per cent of the Northern Territory land mass and 80 per cent of the coastline is under Aboriginal title—in this case, it's under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. A lot of the other 50 per cent is subject to native title, as is the case in Western Australia. What we need to know is: what is the government proposing to do to assist these landholders to develop the north of Australia and leverage their assets so that they can get resources to be able to develop businesses either on their own or in partnership with others? These are very important things that need to be contemplated, and I'm not sure the government has thought through them clearly.

We know that the Joint Standing Committee on Northern Australia is about to undertake an inquiry which will address some of these issues, but these are things that should have been thought of by government previously. There has been a fascination with talking about the tourism industry, the fishing industry and the cattle industry—all very important—but the missing piece in this is the development of the human capital of northern Australia and the human capital which exists within the First Nations communities across the north, whether it is in the Kimberley, the Pilbara, the Northern Territory, Far North Queensland, Cape York or the Torres Strait. These people need to be engaged with, and it's important that the parliament understands what the government is proposing to do to assist and work with First Nations people so that they can be part of a productive workforce going forward and develop businesses on their own country and on their own water to benefit them, their communities and the national economy.

There are a lot of other questions I'd like to ask, such as on Roads of Strategic Importance and what the government's time frame is for the development of Roads of Strategic Importance. A little later, I might get the opportunity to articulate what those questions are.

Mr TAYLOR (Hume—Minister for Energy and Emissions Reduction) (18:55): I thank the member for his questions and his strong interest in infrastructure investment in northern Australia and the role of local Indigenous people in those projects. These are important questions. There are enormous resource opportunities in the north—the Beetaloo Basin and many other projects which the federal government is involved with, and I'll come back to that in a moment. I do want to point out, though, that I'm extremely disappointed that the shadow minister for resources hasn't come along to his own consideration in detail. I would've thought this was a sufficient priority for him to turn up to. The member for Hunter has been acting oddly lately. There has been some odd behaviour. He's been busy constructing a new carbon tax for the opposition, I think, and clearly doesn't have enough time to come along to the consideration in detail.

Let me make a few comments about NAIF and the role that NAIF is playing. The member for Lingiari is right to say there's a very important role that NAIF needs to play in the development of northern Australia, and it's already doing exactly that. It's made a total of 11 investment decisions so far, with two conditional credit approvals on top of that. They're significant investments. In fact, they total now approximately $1.4 billion of investment, supporting projects with an estimated total capital of $2.8 billion. So the government is leveraging significant private sector investment alongside the investment coming from the NAIF.

There are three investment projects for the Northern Territory, five in Western Australia and three in Queensland. That's made up of $781 million for Queensland, $345 million for the Northern Territory and just under $300 million for Western Australia. In total, those projects are expected to deliver $2.6 billion in public benefit for northern Australia. That includes a forecast of just under 4,000 jobs, including Indigenous jobs in construction and during the operations. The draw-downs that will come from those projects have already commenced for three of them. As at 27 August, the department has made total payments of about $42 million, including into the Onslow Marine Support Base, the Voyages Indigenous Tourism Australia project and the Humpty Doo Barramundi project. These are all important contributions to northern Australia.

I will also point out more directly in my own portfolio the work that's going on in the Beetaloo. We see an enormous opportunity in the Beetaloo, with a gas resource that looks to be as good as any we've ever seen in Australia. It's particularly good because it has some of the same characteristics as the gas resources that have revolutionised gas in the United States. It's wet gas; it has oil as well as gas coming from it, and that changes the economics dramatically. In the budget, we made a very significant contribution to getting the Beetaloo developments happening. We're working closely now with the local Indigenous communities up there because they are important stakeholders in these projects. We see enormous potential for jobs, for exports and, importantly, for improving the affordability and reliability of the gas market on the east coast of Australia. It will be connected in through the gas pipeline network to the rest of Australia. So this is a very, very important project, and one that we are absolutely delighted that the Northern Territory government is supporting us on. It's a disappointment that other states in Australia are not showing that kind of foresight. Indeed, it's tragic that the Victorian government has shown no interest in gas—none whatsoever! In fact, they've banned onshore gas exploration and development, in contrast to the Northern Territory government, which sees the opportunity there.

I will make a final comment about northern Australian roads, because the member opposite asked about the Roads of Strategic Importance, the northern Australia package, which is a $1.7 billion package for projects over 10 years. It's all part of our $100 billion infrastructure project. Of course, it's not congestion we are busting up in Queensland; we're busting the time it takes to move people and product around. Getting access to market is absolutely crucial for beef producers and other producers of goods up in the Northern Territory. Under the NABRP, the Northern Australia Beef Roads Program, there are 37 projects, of which 36 have been approved. We have a strong commitment to northern Australia, and it's a commitment I know northern Australia will deliver back in great bounty for the people of Australia and northern Australia.

Mr BRENDAN O'CONNOR (Gorton) (19:00): I want to touch on another matter. I appreciate the fact that the minister kept her opening comments brief to allow questions and comments to be made on the department and government issues. The one matter that I want to touch upon, if I could, is the issue of not being able to use the 'Australian Made' logo for many of our companies and many Australian products. In fact, since 30 June this year, we have products that are not able to use what is a very commercially advantageous logo on those products for those companies and for the workers that produce those products. There's been a failure to ensure that they are able to gain that advantage, because of the inability of those companies to label their products in such a way. This matter has some history. Indeed, it has been at least 12 months since the government could have acted. The advice I've received is that, in the broad, the other jurisdictions are supportive of this matter being resolved. I don't think there's a significant contest or argument amongst jurisdictions about this issue. It really seems to be incumbent on the minister to convene a meeting of the counterpart ministers in state and territory jurisdictions in order to expedite this issue.

What companies are saying to me is they're putting millions of dollars into investment. Arguably this is a $5 billion industry. Thirty thousand workers rely upon this industry for their livelihoods, and yet the government has been derelict in that it has failed to ensure this matter was resolved so that the 'Made in Australia' logo—a very famous and popular logo allowing for commercial advantage of Australian products—was to be used in that way. Since, as I said, 30 June it has been unable to be used. I'm asking the minister what regulatory steps the government will be taking, whether its regulation or legislation. What other steps, engaging other jurisdictions, will be undertaken in order to ensure this problem is fixed? What time frame will be outlined so we can expedite this issue? It's gone on too long and it needs to be fixed. Really, the government needs to explain itself and outline a path to resolution, because there's great uncertainty and great anxiety. We can see, potentially, job losses and profit losses. It's in the government's remit to fix this. The questions are about when and how.

Dr ALLEN (Higgins) (19:03): Yesterday in this place I spoke about the jobs of the future, the need to invest in a changing workforce and the importance of ensuring our children have the skills to succeed in this changing world. I spoke about how we must strive for excellence and how we need to be at the forefront of ensuring we have job-ready students for the future. With 75 per cent of jobs in the future slated to require skills in science, technology, engineering and mathematics, it is now more than ever important that we arm our students with the skills.

As a medical researcher, I have seen firsthand how early STEM education has long-reaching effects in health innovation and how this, ultimately, saves lives. As a university professor, I feel incredibly privileged to have supervised dozens of higher education students to undertake honours, masters and PhDs. They have gone on to help society understand why things are happening and how to find evidence based solutions to questions such as why food allergies are on the rise, how to best feed our infants in the safest possible way, how to prevent diseases through improved immunisation, how to have improved screening programs and optimal food safety through improved food labelling, and how to use the genetic revolution to help society.

In my electorate of Higgins in Melbourne, health and science are in the top five employers. We have a large population of students at the primary and secondary stages and also a very large group of undergraduate and postgraduate students. With regard to primary and secondary students, we need to ensure that all students are able to access the information they need to have a good, solid foundation in STEM, regardless of the school they went to or where they live. We want the next generation to be a generation of big ideas and great understanding and to lead the world in innovation, science and technology. We need businesses to be open to change and to recognise the potential and value the skills of STEM that our students are learning.

In years gone by, jobs were often gendered. Girls were flight attendants; boys were pilots. Boys were mechanics, plumbers and electricians; girls were teachers, nurses and receptionists. That is not the case now, and I'm pleased to say that we are in the time of geek girls. Women and girls are coders, scientists, aerospace engineers and astronauts, and I'd like to take the opportunity to recognise one of my great mentors, Professor Ruth Bishop AO, who, in 1972, discovered rotavirus at my home institution, the Royal Children's Hospital. Her discovery has led to a rotavirus vaccine that literally saves hundreds of thousands of lives every year around the world. She should have got a Nobel Prize; I wish she had.
